awd_titl_txt: Role of Fiber-matrix Interactions During Failure in Fiber Reinforced Tissues
awd_abstract_narration:
Many biological tissues throughout the body are fiber-reinforced composites, built primarily of water, collagen fibers, and a soft extrafibrillar matrix. Failure or tearing of these tissues causes pain and disability. Tissue composition and molecular architecture are important to the tissue mechanical properties both during physiological loading and during failure. To date, there has been insufficient research focused on molecular level failure mechanics of fiber-reinforced tissues such as the intervertebral discs of the spine. Determining tissue failure properties and the roles that the various molecules of the tissue play in failure behavior is important for preventing disc disease and to designing new medical approaches for repairing the disc. The goal of this project is to determine how the fiber-reinforced tissue structure controls damage mechanics. For this work the PI will focus on the annulus fibrosus of the intervertebral disc because of its cross-ply fiber architecture and medical relevance.  The educational outreach effort in this project is an expansion of the Girls in Engineering (GiE) Summer Program coordinated by the College of Engineering at Berkeley. The PI also will train graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds in her laboratory during performance of the research project. 

In this project, the PI will evaluate the role of the extrafibrillar matrix composition and fiber composition and network on time-dependent and -independent failure behavior. She will combine computational and experimental techniques to study failure mechanisms of fiber-reinforced materials, such as stress distributions between fibers and the extrafibrillar matrix. Her research team will leverage its previous work that developed an experimental method for robust failure testing of the annulus fibrosus. Data from tissue-level experiments will be incorporated into the existing finite element model of the disc joint to elucidate the role of fiber-matrix interactions during joint-level failure. In broader terms, the unique computational model developed from this research, where the extrafibrillar matrix and collagen fibers are described as separate and distinct materials will be beneficial for material scientists outside of biomechanics research (e.g., carbon fiber reinforced polymers) and for scientists investigating the contribution of fibers and extrafibrillar matrix on tissue mechanics (sub-failure and failure mechanics) with injury, aging, or repair.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
This project assessed the contribution of individual components on the mechanical behavior of the annulus fibrosus (AF) from the intervertebral disc under uniaxial tension. The AF is a highly organized fiber-reinforced tissue. Due to the stiff collagen fiber structure, this material is difficult to grip and test in tension to failure. Therefore, new experimental techniques were developed to ensure mechanical testing of stiff slippery materials without slippage at the grips. Secondly, samples were prepared in a modified notch-geometry to ensure failure at the mid-substance without stress concentrations from the grip line impacting results, which occurs for typical rectangular shaped specimens used to test biological tissues.

The role of water content, glycosaminoglycan content, and collagen crosslinking on AF subfailure and failure properties were assessed. This project determined the proper swelling conditions to test AF tissue as ‘fresh’, which highlighted major discrepancies between previously reported values and true mechanical properties of the AF. In short, typical testing protocols for the AF results in overhydration, causing the previously reported mechanical properties to be under-reported by 67%.

The experimental data collected as part of this project was used to develop and validate a multi-scale structure based model of the AF. This model allowed us to evaluate the roll of each tissue subcomponent (e.g., water and glycosaminoglycan content) and stress distributions throughout the tissue. This approach can also be applied to synthetic fiber-reinforced materials. The findings from the model also predicted anisotropy in the formation and mechanical contribution of collagen crosslinks.

The outreach program performed during the project years engaged high school students in under-resourced schools in problem solving activities, which can be applied beyond STEM fields. It also provided peer-mentorship in understanding college and opportunities in college by engaging undergraduate and graduate students in the design and implementation process. The college of engineering at Berkeley is expanding upon this work by setting up an Engineering Ambassador program.

Overall, work from this project resulted in 21 publications, including conference proceedings and peer-reviewed journal articles.

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2022
Modified by: Grace O'connell
